comments.commentBody: What I am most surprised from these data is that health related statistics, particularly healthy life expectance. I don't see much difference between US and China in spite of huge difference in environment such as pollution on air, water and arable land and human body contamination with antibiotic. According to Chinese government data, 20% of arable land in China is contaminated with dangerous heavy metals because of the water contamination. China's air pollution is notorious. And yet, healthy life expectance in China is 76.8 years vs. ours 77.5 years old. This tells me that either their statistics are wrong or our high level obesity, nearly two thirds are obese or over-weighted, is shortening our healthy life expectance.

Memma, I hope you weren't implying I am one of those voters. I would never vote for Trump. But I did vote for Obama. I just find Trump quite amusing. And as a Vietnam veteran, it's kind of hard for me to take this news article with the appropriate and politically correct gravitas demanded by you. I also never took seriously that GOP smear campaign used against Bill Clinton as a "draft dodger" in his first run for president. And I voted for him. How you can take this news article seriously does actually bewilder me a bit. But you are entitled to your opinion. I've mellowed out in my old age about the Vietnam War. And how partisan politics is played like a blood sport in this country. I just find it absurd we're still fighting over the Vietnam War. After the fall of Saigon in April, 1975, we all know what a disaster this war was. Yet here we are almost five decades after the war still fighting about the war. So Trump is a pathological liar. What else is new when it comes to politics in this country?  Hillary Clinton voted for the Iraq War aa senator and then lobbied as secretary of state for Obama to get the US involved in the Libyan ivil war. Both are now foreign policy debacles that rank with the Vietnam War.  And she'll probably be our next president. That's as absurd as what Trump has said about the Vietnam War in this article. I get the feeling, though I am a Vietnam veteran, you feel I am not entitled to my own sense of humor about the war. Now that's really absurd.

I also respect your service to our country and I do agree with you about Bush. He's just as bad as McCain. But that wasn't the issue I was trying to get across in my comments. I refuse to react like a bull charging at the red cape of the matador when someone waves old glory at me. When it comes to patriotism and who did or didn't serve in the military or the war, it all seems from my old age to be the theater of the absurd. And it amuses me that with a volunteer armed forces (Nixon got rid of it in 1973), most of these commenters on this article have no skin in the game. They are all sitting up in the bleachers. But they are so detached from the real drama on the playing field, namely, of the pain and shared sacrifice our young men and women have shown in the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq . Max, you and I are the exception to the rule. We are actually veterans. So I could care less how they react with emotion to Trump's outlandish lies and comic bravado. And of course, I would never vote for him.

The real issue which the NYT should consider as a topic for its readers to have is a serious debate and sincere about this topic: Should We Bring Back The Draft? I wouldn't hold your breath on that issue receiving the coverage that Trump has received from NYT editors in this article. Our country can ill afford the growing chasm, which is deep and wide, between civilians and soldiers and who must go off and fight these wars. Our republic is endangered. Now I am being serious.

George, I think the point of much of the criticism is the hypocrisy of so many right wing chicken-hawks.  It is one thing to not serve and quite another to have taken deferments when it was your time and then later beat the drums of war at the drop of a hat.

I served in Vietnam (31 May 1967 - 31 May 1968). But I lucked out because Uncle Sam made me a corpsman, and I was stationed at Cam Ranh Bay AFB.  I was in the rear with the gear and the beer, even though the base was attacked several times with mortars and rockets during the Tet Offensive of 1968. But grunts took three-day in-country R&R at the base. To be quite frank, bringing up who served and who stayed behind is just another ideological red herring brought out during every presidential campaign since I returned to the Big PX. I refuse to play into this game. Looking back on my tour of duty there, I find all the patients who passed through the hospital where I served as victims of that tragic war. And that includes Sen. John McCain. But despite the living hell he endured at the Hanoi Hilton, he is an embarassement of epic proportions to me because he's always beating his little tin drum for the next war. And I never held it against former Vice President Dick Cheney that he had told the press he had "other priorities" during the Vietnam War. But Vice President Joe Biden also got many deferments during the draft. He just doesn't talk about it. So he can keep his mouth shut. I hold no grudges. I'm just tired of these verbal food fights during the race for the White House. They remind me of that classic scene in the cafeteria in "Animal House." Sen. McCain started it when he said only crazies would vote for the Trump. He just should have kept his mouth shut like Biden.

Dr. K,

The problem, as your FRED chart shows, economic growth cannot be achieved with tax cuts. Growth is a more complex than tax cuts. Putting more investment dollars in the hands of the well-off has not worked. Somehow the 1% seem to enjoy making money off of money rather than stimulate investment in goods like public works that benefits the whole society.

History shows that countries flourish when government invests in natural monopolies that is better managed as a collective service. I am surprised that the GOP candidates have not picked up on DeWitt Clinton, A. Lincoln, T. Roosevelt, D. Eisenhower, and new revelations from the Nixon Library that he was interested in global warming in the 60s.

I hope you are not only talking Abenomics but you are spending time with Mr. Abe. I like him. It is sad that Japan and the US are not joining forces to demonstrate the 2nd gen superconducting Maglev, the new derivative based on Powell and Danby's inventions proved by Japan.

The US, Japan & the World needs this system to improve the efficiency of logistics & travel systems. The new Maglev is cheaper & a lot more capable. It can haul automobiles & trucks in roll-on, roll-off Maglev vehicles, it can electronically switch, & it will operate on Maglev adapted railroad tracks. http://youtu.be/Db4_PUbXMqM It is a perfect system for inter & intra city commuting. We have studied the NYC system & we could operate without subsidy & reduce fares on the largest system in America.

All things that come with self-imposed superlatives come to a tragic end. Titanic-the fastest biggest etc.; and Hindenburg- biggest etc. -were brought down by the unexpected. Time will tell as to how Mr. Trump’s Presidential aspiration ends. And if it reaches the logical end Mr. Trump expects his quest to attain then God exists and he (cannot be she when Mr. Trump is involved) is punishing the US for its sins.
Name the winning of the last three World Series.  What were their records going into the playoffs?  There is no basis in fact for a five-percent estimate.

Fran: 1988 Dodgers, 2006 Cardinals and (almost) the 1973 Mets.
What do they have in common? Pitching. If DeGrom, Harvey, Matz and Colon or Syndegaard are dealing, why NOT the Mets?
Now the sixth best record.

Missing from this discussion is the fact that winning a world series is in Mr Harvey's best interest as well as the Mets'.  No matter how good he is, Harvey might not get another chance (think Ernie Banks).  Add in the fact that there is no data clearly showing that exceeding 180 innings actually does increase the chance of reinjuring the elbow, and it's not clear that it is not also in Harvey's long-term best interest to pitch n the post-season.  As far as I can see, the only one involved who doesn't benefit if the Mets have a successful post season run is Scott Boras.
How many bullets did Trump dodge at his prep school? And how many buddies did he see blown to bits?

Mr Trump's equating his Military School experience to knowing the Military fits his Readers Digest approach perfectly to almost every topic brought up in his campaign. When asked where he gets his Military advise from he said from watching Military experts on TV- Seriously. When asked which ones he smiled and said You know, all of them, all the big ones (VP candidate Sarah Palin got throughly roasted for telling Katie Couric that she got all her information from reading magazines and newspapers- but could hardly answer which ones- this is where her slogan "Gotcha Questions" was born)  Trump knows all about the boarder because he's met some boarder patrol officers. He doesn't have to know the names of heads of states now- because "They change all the time" and by the time he gets to the white house they will all be different- So he will wait till he gets into office.
The technical term is *excrement*, as in "The supply siders have covered themselves in excrement," a natural consequence of the execrable logic.

oops...it should be Li Ka Shing...http://www.forbes.com/profile/li-ka-shing/
...he is a wonderful person w a "heart of gold," both literally & figuratively!

OMG! This article makes me want to vomit. Having worked at Stanford University for almost 14 years & "stewarded" many Chinese donors, including Li Ka sing, the 9th richest man in the world, I believe most Chinese high-tech folks have absolutley no idea about passion/creativity/thinking "outside the box." They come to Silicon Valley having spent years in formal education and looking for "pat, shallow" answers" for "success" and don't have any idea about creativity/imagination/passion, etc.

I own a lot of shares of SWKS, (Skyworks Solutions, which makes hardware for Apple, etc) thus, I want a financially-successful US-China relationship. But letting China call the shots on the rules for technology between the US & another country could not be more stupid. I have seen this stupidity first hand in terms of students at Stanford as well as rich Chinese donors/prospects looking to Silicon Valley to make money.

Perhaps it is time to dump my SWKS stock if China is going to assume such power.
Remember Steffi ?

Margaret Court won 11 of her slams at her home Open Australian, at a time when most players did not even bother to travel that far down, and when Women's tennis was far less competitive. Prize is so much more now which brings in new competition. Also, most of her titles were pre-Open era. Pros did not even compete.

Graf won the majority of her slams post Seles stabbing. After Seles turned barely 16, she won everywhere, and Graf was the 2nd best. Seles won 7 of the 8 slams she entered after turning 16, yes just 16. Even at the time of stabbing she was not even 19. Graf was looking distraught and had not much confidence or hope, and it took a disgraceful stabbing by a German fan to alter history.

The best 3 of all time are Serena, Martina N, and Evert. By far.

Yes. There is a lot of doubt. Note that Serena, in her prime, has gotten dumped out of 12 Slams before the quarterfinals. That's more than Graf (once), Evert (twice), and Navratilova (three times) combined.

Evert made 34 Slam semis in a row. Navratilova 18. Graf 16. Serena has never managed more than 7 in a row .

Navratilova made 14 Slam finals in a row. Graf 13. Evert 10. Serena has never made more than 5 in a row.

Additionally, Serena benefits from the fact that most of the other top players are woefully inconsistent. In winning the first three Slams this year, for example, she's only had to win two matches against top 10 seeds (Sharapova both times). She's going to make it to the Final of the US Open without having beat any of the top 20 seeds, in a tournament where only three of the top eight women's seeds even made it out of the third round.

Serena is a great player, but she is much more inconsistent than previous greats and benefits from being able to beat up on a comparatively weak field (imagine if she had to beat either Evert or Martina in every single tournament to win a Slam).
Is there any doubt anywhere that Serena is by far the greatest female tennis player in history? No one ever worked harder for this Slam, or deserved it more. Bravo, Serena!

My thoughts? Goodell and the rest of the NFL execs/owners are exploiting their positions to an incredible extreme, taking advantage of cities and communities with exorbitant tax concessions, taking advantage of players, many of which end up broken and destitute, and any employees that they feel are recourse-less, including these hard working women; all while laughing all the way to the bank ($44m in 1 year; sheesh). They get to make the rules, what do we expect?

I certainly enjoy the game, but the more I learn about it's ugly underbelly, the more it sickens me. America at it's worst. Would love to see them taken down a peg or three.
As many organizations in the NFL are learning, Citizenship matters.  Manziel may have learned.  Winston may yet have to learn.  Apparently, Smith has learned nothing.  Another Draft Day bust?

No, to suggest that two extremely gifted and competitive athletes would "fix" a competition is racist. To suggest that they'd try to win on anything other than ability is disrespectful of their talent.  It demonstrates what is the core of racist thinking, a fundamental disrespect for another's accomplishments, and more importantly, their being. No  one has ever suggested collusion in any of the other great tennis rivalries.  Why would you here? Some of the best rivalries are among siblings, as the Williams sisters consistently demonstrate   Mauresmo was out line as were most of the William's sisters original critics. The two are among the greatest ever and Serena is probably the greatest.

I'm rooting for them.

Long board meeting tonight. Lots of frogs out there and very few princes.
What amazing women !
What an amazing woman!

@Paul Bellerose Terrace
You are, as always, spot on with your observations. But in this case, you are --How do you say it?--'Preaching to the Choir'.
As a Berliner and a DFB fan, I actually have a clue of what's going on in the Bundesliga-- And also as it is reported in the German Press. That said, It's good to encounter not only another DFB fan, but a great statistician as well.
By the way. I totally agree with you. Pep should say Adios! -- (But first sign an agreement to keep Goetze off the bench, before he goes!!)
And one more thing. I, for one never "underestimated" Thomas Tuchel, nor the fact that he would prove himself with Dortmund. One of the best things Herr Klopp could've done for his beloved team was to nominate him, and BVB is looking good!! ... I just hope they can manage to hold onto all their best players, including (and especially) Roman Buerki!!!
As for now. Es geht voran....It goes onward. Next stop Ireland.

Hah!
When I led our choir tours in Eastern Europe, we got to the point where we told our hosts that we had "vegetarians", since they were simply not able to comprehend that some of our students ate kosher. Every single place we went, there was ham/pork/schweinfleisch/bacon in EVERYTHING we were served. "Of course is vegetarian. But what" they invariably replied, "would you do without FLAVOR?"

One such tour ended in Venice - where they brought out huge vats of green salad. The students disappeared the salad instantly. Signor Pietro clapped his hands, three more vats appeared, then disappeared. A second time, he clapped his hands, three more vats of green salad. He looked at me with a questioning eye. I shrugged and explained, "we've been in Germany..."
That wouldn't make any material difference.  Even in Kansas, relatively few people work directly on farms nowadays.
You could say the same about California.

I like the graphic, but wouldn't it have been better to show *all* employees instead of non-farm employees? Kansas, after all, is primarily an agricultural state and farm employment is more significant there than most other parts of the country.

Johnny Frog is a platform style game that will give you hours of fun. Follow Johnny through his travel around the world, pick the power-ups and keep the frog alive.
A lot of different levels and challenges!
Will you be able to reach the end?
:)

https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.ONIRALIA.Johnny_Frog
you are right Ron! thank you for taking this stand!!

I think a small round of sanctions should be considered before Xi arrives on his planned visit to break up this party. Now China is trying to put a wedge between our gov't and our tech industries. Now is the time to do it. Everything the Chinese do coincides with what our gov't is planning to do. Now is the time to break that pattern. Sanctions.

It would be an even bigger number if the time period were doubled.  This comes to $500 billion/year, worldwide.  That's an average of roughly $150 per person per year.  (World urban population into total dollars.)  That's significant; it doesn't need trillions piled on.
Why penalize students for an issue they didn't create and over which they have no control.  The villains here are the federal government and American tech companies.
85% of the PhD's stay here.  China experiences massive brain drain.

I'm not sure. They send kids not only to the US but also to European countries, Australia, and Canada. Actually, those countries want to attract more international students (for economical benefits, cultural influence, and future ties with China), so they would appreciate any help from the US. :)

Maybe the US should threaten to eliminate student visas for Chinese nationals, in addition to eliminating H-1B visas.  They may change their tune when they can't send their kids to be educated at US schools.

China ended it's age of exploration after the Star Raft expeditions under Admiral Zheng He a century before Europeans. The Africans, Asians and Europeans were dismissed as ignorant barbarians. The Emperor ordered the massive fleet burned and the end of the expeditions. The Chinese ships were much bigger and more technologically advanced than the European ones.

China invented a written language, gun powder, printing, rockets, guns, steel, double hulled ships with closed compartments, torpedoes, banking and paper money. The Chinese were making steel 1400 years before Europeans. The Europeans rose over the last 500+ years. China sank over the last century primarily from Japanese military aggression. About 23% of the human race is ethnic Han Chinese.

Here is "a load" of reading for you to fill your ignorance about China. See "When China Ruled the Seas" Louise Levathes; "Science and Civilization in China" Joseph Needham; " China, A New History" John K. Fairbank. Then try visiting China for a week or two.
China invented the compass, seismometers, clocks, water and animal powered machines, mass production of parts etc.

From THE WEALTH AND POVERTY OF NATIONS by David S. Landes, Norton, 1998:

Page 49 "The clock was the greatest achievement of medieval
mechanical ingenuity."

Page 50 "The mechanical clock remained a European (Western) monopoly for some three hundred years in its higher forms....The Chinese built a few astronomical water clocks in the Tang and Sung eras--complicated and artful pieces that may have kept excellent time in the short run, before they started clogging....The Chinese treated time and knowledge of time as a confidential aspect of sovereignty, not to be shared with the people."

Forgive me for not taking the time and effort needed to address the other assertions of this poster. I consider it fortuitous that Landes also pointed out above the source of so much of China's continuing technical and scientific backwardness, the governments it has suffered.

For most of the past 2200 years China has been a socioeconomic political educational scientific technological world superpower. Ruling with the Mandate of Heaven the Middle/Central Kingdom ignored any entangling economic, military, political or colonial alliances with the "barbarians."

In Deng Xiaoping's economically politically reformed China there is a term limited collective leadership trying improve the economic status of it's citizens. China has invested in American business. China makes cheap goods for Americans and buys American debt. While China has the nominal #2 economy by GDP, with 1.3 billion people ranks about 80th -near Bulgaria and Botswana-on a per capita basis. Corruption is a threat to one-party rule. China is aging and shrinking with a massive male gender imbalance. China's air, water and land is polluted.

While America spends three times what China does on it's military. America has economic, political and military alliances. America has 25% of the world prison population with only 5% of it's people. There are more black Americans on welfare, prison and unemployed than ever before. Uncle Sam is spying on Americans without reasonable suspicion or probable cause. Yet in Mandarin the name for America is the "Beautiful Country".
China has only succeeded so far because it has adopted western approaches.  Because it does not want to adopt more western approaches, it will not grow more.  In fact, it looks like it may collapse.
That is what China got - not the U.S. which got a reduced standard of living for the middle class.  BTW, China is the great polluter on the planet thanks to the industrialization we have it promote.
No it is not worth it….we had Westclock-Baby Ben alarm clocks that were and are still really great clocks….no one needs more cheap junk, people need real value for their $.
The USA makes great clocks….buy American made products or shop vintage….great quality and craftsmanship.

The transfer of wealth away from small American businesses and laborers to China is measured in the trillions of dollars over the past two decades. China now has over 400 billionaires thanks in large measure to the 1% in America who facilitate and participate in this transfer of wealth away from the American working class (I'm talking to you, Walmart, among many others).

At some point in the not distant future China will not be dependent upon U.S. for the innovative technology which has given China its ability to participate modern civilization. What does the U.S get out of this? Cheaper alarm clocks? Is that all - is it really worth it?
